Literature Review: The primate brain has evolved complex social cognitive abilities to navigate its intricate social world. Functional specialization in the brain's social cognition networks is a pervasive theme, from the level of single cells to hierarchically organized networks that extract and represent abstract social information. This specialization is not limited to the sensorimotor periphery but is a widespread feature of primate brain organization, involving distinct but interacting subnetworks that traverse large parts of the brain. In this review, we will discuss the functional specialization of social cognition networks in primates, focusing on face processing, social interaction understanding, and mental state attribution. We will also examine the neural basis of social cognition, including the role of parallel systems involved in processing nonsocial information and the common computations applied to different domains. Our analysis will be grounded in a comprehensive review of the existing literature on the neural basis of social cognition in primates, with a focus on the functional brain organization of social cognition networks.
